The algae took a turn the night the well steadied. In the southern vats a bloom that was not theirs made a lace across the surface like a wedding dress no one should wear. It was pretty and then it was vicious. Mira broke the surface with a paddle and wanted to weep because the reflex to save the thing that kills is ancient. She culled with the coldness of a field medic. Two technicians vomited in their mouths and got back on schedule. The murmur behaved like a strategy and then like a superstition and then like physics finding its feet. She pushed sound into the ducts with a precision she called hygiene when anyone else was listening and a word closer to prayer when she was alone. She sent a note to Niobe that said, “Tell your watchers that if they hear a pitch like a coin dropped in a bucket they should send for me,” and Niobe rolled her eyes and sent the instruction, because usefulness does not require aesthetic approval.

Arkady tried to sheath the wells in silk and was told no. He proposed a We Night that would show hands turning cranks in slow motion and water falling from new angles while a line of text promised men that restraint could be beautiful. “No flags,” Ilias said again, and Arkady did not pout because he had slept badly and his appetite for drama had learned to fast. He cut three seconds of silence into a feed on an otherwise dull afternoon and discovered a trick he had not yet grown bored of. He watched the city do nothing and learned a new pleasure that hurt his teeth: the pleasure of not being needed for the thing to hold.

Quill leaned into an afternoon where his head felt like an occupied room and told himself that the ache meant he was still being used by the right work. He sat with Ilias on a step that had been worn down by another city’s shoes and asked a question he did not like asking. “Who will be the mouth when mine goes quiet,” he said, and watched Ilias flinch because succession turns romance into duty. “Lev sometimes,” he said. “The monitors when it’s about edges. You when you are well enough to say nothing and make it heavy. Mira when we need to lie about hope without lying.” Quill nodded, pleased and sad and vain and decent enough to separate those sensations in his mouth. He wrote three sentences and tucked them into his pocket with a superstition that the city would not let him spend them yet. He could not keep from making them beautiful. He put a line in about breath like timber and hated himself for loving it.

Niobe walked with Lev through a corridor that had learned to open at the correct speed and did not comment on the way men leaned back into thresholds with the ease of a taught reflex. She set her hand on Lev’s shoulder and felt the heat under the brace. “You’re doing this without martyrdom,” she said, which in her lexicon was affection. Lev did not shrug off the hand. “I’ve wanted to break smaller things than men,” she said. “This work lets my hands be clean and tired.” “You’ll be asked to be a symbol,” Niobe said. “Refuse with boredom.” Lev grinned with half a mouth. “Boredom is my one good suit,” she said, and they both laughed without showing teeth because the corridor did not deserve their laughter as decoration.

Bram’s map put on weight where the manual grace had been charted. He began to send crank posts into the richer blocks because nothing breaks a city as quickly as uneven dignity. A man who had always eaten warm without counting found his hand on a wheel and discovered his back’s honesty. He disliked it and returned the next day because disliking and respect can share a room. Bram took the calls from men who felt insulted by labor and answered them with names of soldiers without medals and the hours those men had stood in the rain on purpose. He surprised himself by not raising his voice once in a week, and then raised it once and felt human again.

The Procession of Turning Back diminished in headcount and amplified in fidelity. Men came without feeling watched by their own need to be seen, which is a sign of maturity or of exhaustion and either way a relief. Ilias took his place in the line and turned his hand near the ribbon and stepped away without practicing a face. He thought of Jaro’s sink and felt the suede of envy for the old man’s clarity. He saw a woman across the room who stood the way a person stands when the rooms have been built without her in mind and wondered if she was the girl with the jar grown into a person who had learned to withhold her mercy until it would not excuse anyone. He did not follow her because wanting to weave a world into a neat tale was an old vice he had been trying to starve.

Sima intercepted two more boys in the wrong stacks because boys, like fungi, find their way into dark corners if you build enough shelves. She did not shame them. She gave them a pencil and a catalog and told them to index the foxes. “There are no foxes,” one said. “There are drawings,” Sima said. “Index the lies and you’ll learn what people needed to borrow.” The boy with a mouth that promised trouble wrote, under F, FOLK FOX: SEE ALSO—EXITS, and surprised himself with pleasure at having organized a fiction. He came back the next day and did it again because arranging other people’s mistakes gives the hands a mercy receiving does not.

Rain came the way it does now, as a coarse hushing that does not wet but dims. Men stood in doorways out of habit. The murmurs in the vents twined with the sound as if to remind the building of work. A child pressed his face to a pane and left a print that looked like a map of a river expanding and then withdrawing. Mira ran a dish outside and brought it in and filmed the thing that looked like water deciding not to commit and wrote a line on her board that she erased and hid in her mouth: if rain stops being itself long enough it becomes a warning and a wish. She did not show the clip to Arkady. She watched the men hum under the sound and did not tell them their pitch had dropped in a way her instruments liked.

One night, late, a man who had been busy failing Ratio True gathered himself up and took his boots to the well. He put his hands on the wheel with the intimacy of a confession and turned until his shoulders lost their toys. He cried once, a dry thing, then breathed and pedaled until the water in the basin found a new rhythm and the duct above him remembered to keep time. No one filmed him. Lev sat with her back to the wall and did not ask why. When he left he did not thank her. She did not need thanks, though she would have liked sometimes to be told that her work had made boredom bearable for a man who had learned to hunger for drama as a proof of life.

The vault’s seed performed its betrayal again, which is to say it obeyed its nature. Mira killed it first again, which is to say she obeyed hers. She found herself feeling like a murderer and wrote, I am a boundary, in a margin so small she had to squint to see if it was true. The third grain she set under a bell. She reduced the light when it begged. She whispered once, because whispering belongs to women who don’t intend to be caught praying, and then stopped because she had to be accountable to herself. She called Niobe and said, “We are going to make this into a school,” and Niobe said, “I am building the door that will keep worship out,” and Mira said, “I don’t know if worship can be kept out of anything that promises a shape of future,” and Niobe said, “Then we will be weavers and saboteurs in the same breath.”

Arkady watched the city choose a dull virtue and felt something inside him go still in a way that was not death. He edited a clip of hands turning and took the music off it and left the squeak in place. He told his team to capture fewer faces and more small failures. He installed a light in his office that hums at a frequency a bee might respect and rolled his eyes at himself and then sat in the hum for an hour and discovered that he could live without an audience for the length of sixty minutes. He did not tell anyone, because his power depended on the city thinking he needed them to exist, and he did, but not always.

Bram wrote a letter to the block that had failed twice in a tone he would have mocked in another man. He wrote, You are not being punished. We miscalculated. He wrote, Come turn, and then crossed it out and wrote, Sit with a crank until the map forgets what your name is and remembers your weight. He signed his name and then ripped the page and rewrote it because who you are when you commit yourself to paper will be used against you on a day when your patience is low. He took his fists apart with his other hand the way a person reduces a knot by rolling it and sent the letter and did not care if anyone mocked him on a feed because he is one of those men who cannot help but prefer a room where someone is working to one where someone is speaking.

Niobe took Ilias to a corridor at midnight where the floor had been polished by shoes that meant well. She said, “You are becoming useful,” and he laughed and then did not, because the compliment was edged. “I am learning to give up rooms,” he said. She set a pencil on his hand and pressed until the point dented. “You were born without the instinct to leave space,” she said. “We taught you a trick. Keep it.” He said, “If I get in the way drag me,” and she smiled a thin smile that had nothing to do with humor. “I won’t drag you,” she said. “I will throw you down an elevator shaft and ask Arkady for three seconds of silence,” and he said, “Yes,” and it made both of them happier than they deserved.

Sima put the keys back under her shirt and went home by a route that took her past a chalk fox that had acquired a companion who was either a dog or a child’s misunderstanding of a dog. She considered erasing the second animal and didn’t, because there is a mercy in letting a lie multiply when it is harmless and perhaps useful later as an index entry. She put Jaro’s chair under the skylight and did not remove it even though the room needed the space, because objects sometimes argue with utility in a way the living should be allowed to learn from. She allowed herself to say a name out loud and decided that doing so did not turn her into a priest.

The east warehouses produced not a fox but a rat with ambition and a coat that had learned to shine under a camera. The rumor was elevated anyway because men prefer foxes and a rumor so often does not care to be corrected. A boy drew ears sharper than any real animal would consent to carry and someone chalked the word TRUE beneath it and someone else wrote WE over the top and no one fought. The image wore both captions easily. Arkady shot the wall and did not air it. He kept it in a drawer marked famine. He had begun to store not beauty or rage, but quiets he could use later when the city forgot it had learned how.

Ilias wrote on his wall beneath the admonition about buildings a line from Jaro and another he had stolen from himself. Build sinks, not altars. Make less into not loss. He laughed once at the hubris of giving himself commandments and then found that laughing made them easier to disobey. He put his hand to his chest and pressed until the muscle objected, then took the hand away. He went to a room where men knew his name and did not use it because they were busy with a wheel. He told them nothing, which is the truest test of a speaker. He left after an hour feeling hungry in a way that had nothing to do with food and everything to do with being kept from his favored vice by a set of small, honest tasks.

The city’s next failure wanted spectacle and never got it. A door decided to read an outstretched palm as a wall and stayed shut until a kneeling body taught it humility. A valve refused a command until a girl half the weight of any man in the room leaned her shoulder against a lever and showed it how to be a gate again. A queue got tired and sat and remembered it knew how to be a room full of human beings without turning every inch into a proof of skin. The feeds carried three seconds of silence after each nothing and the city, which had been trained to read that space as a sentence, let the grammar hold. Father Quill spent his three sentences wisely and then stopped talking and began to get well in the only way that matters here: he learned to be useless for an hour without calling it a fast.

Mira finally let the third sprout be, under glass and with watchfulness that was more like suspicion than like love. She did not call Niobe because sometimes the act of not calling is the content of trust. She wrote on a card in the smallest hand she had, Boundary held, and set it beside a dish. She had learned to set her own oaths where only she could read them and still let them count. She closed her eyes and did not whisper. The murmur hummed in the duct and the room’s air sat still with the dignity of a room that has learned to be kind to lungs. Outside, the men took turns with a wheel that moved nothing but eased their hands. In the archive, Sima turned a page with irritation because the paper had torn under a rough finger in 198 before anyone alive in the room was born, and still it angered her.

There was no grand motion toward salvation. The city leaned another millimeter into a competence that might someday be mistaken for grace. Ilias stood in a doorway and listened to the sound of air and water arguing gently in the well and decided that he had built at least one thing that would make no one proud. He smiled without teeth. He did not think of the last hare. He thought of a sink and of not losing. He turned and went toward the part of the map that had begun to think of itself as his work. He intended to bore a room into choosing, and was, for once, content to be a man with a ledger instead of a god with a burnable world.
